snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly? I just finished playing a few minutes ago, and I‚Äôm feeling like I‚Äôm kind of done with the game at this point. I really loved it at first, but I just can‚Äôt deal with the rats anymore. This game rewards horrifyingly bad behavior, and I‚Äôm growing tired of the gameplay loop because of it. 

I‚Äôm sick of gathering materials, upgrading my gear, organizing my loadout, loading into a map and spending 15-20 minutes looting, only to be shot in the back and forced to leave with nothing‚Ä¶ and then having to start that process ALL over again.

The bottom line is that I shouldn‚Äôt have to adapt to these types of players, or create special strategies to deal with them. The devs either need to start actively punishing players who rat, or make it so that kill hungry players show up on your map if they frequently engage in combat. If not that, then maybe they should make PvP and PvE seperate altogether. 

All I know is that if they don‚Äôt do something soon, the game will absolutely die.

So far, this is my rule of thumb: I trust people with a mic more than someone who emotes. And all alliances are off the moment decent loot becomes available.

If I team up with a chatter box or a mute to take down a big arc, I'm not going to be surprised if they turn on me the second the arc goes down.

snippet.textDisplay: The rats make me want to be a rat.... but for all the wrong reasons - and for whatever reason ( yes, I know it's just a game) I can't "be the rat." That said, the rats are really what makes the game what it is. Without the rats ( say, friendly fire does nothing for example), it would just be PVE and boring after 10 or 15 hours. THAT said, I'm just having to come to terms that I will always be the old guy who gets his stuff stolen, and never be a rat. Are the rats actually "rats" in real life? Probably.

snippet.textDisplay:
I thought I had seen every rat trick in the book. I check corners, look ahead, run when needed cover to cover. I called a lift the other day, on solo, waited a little before going in. Usually I have been tossing a smoke or two just to provide some cover. It was so quiet this time I didn‚Äôt. I went to the computer and started closing the lift. Bam, hit from behind by a rat POS. I turned, had a good shotgun and returned fire from cover. Then, another rat POS hit me from behind, again! So remember people, rats swarm together even on solo. 
Great point on those high areas inside rooms, I check corners but not always up‚Ä¶
Over all, I find most people are chill if you use proximity on solo‚Ä¶but not always.

snippet.textDisplay: On our shared account here: I have very recently been posting my comments on videos like this expressing how much I do not like this toxic behavior and of course I have received numerous responses all along the lines of ‚Äú It‚Äôs an extraction shooter, this game is not for casuals blah blah blah‚Äù. snippet.textDisplay: Yeah, I gave up on this game. I'll never understand the hype for developer's that allow others to screw up your game play. They say " Dont get scared of losing your loot!" Ok, then that takes away the hard work you put in getting your parts. Sneaking around, hoping that person who said "friendly" really means it. Getting to extract and being shot at. Yeah, im not going through all that just to say " Meh, I'll get my stuff again." I read the devs were thinking about either making a pve mode or pve entirely but they said it was dull and boring. If giving players the option to be toxic to each other at free will is what decided on that, than you need to go back to the drawing board. I think theres TONS of people who would play this solo and matchup just to work together. The bots can be challenging enough. Just my opinion, have fun out there.

snippet.textDisplay: This game desperatly needs a PvE co-op mode. As a casual player, teaming up to fight the game is fun. Teaming up to fight off others, so you can fight the game is not. Forced PvP discourages from using any good guns because you don't want to 'give them' to some random, next rat, just shooting you right after he said 'dont shoot'. Not using good guns prevents from progressing, thus I loose any interest in further playing the game alltogether. All because of that forced pvp, that kills the huge potential this world has. Forced PvP is the worst. Give players a choice. I'm not saying remove PvP, just add a dedicated pve mode alongside and let the player base choose which playstyle they want to focus on. Right now there is to much power in the wrong hands - players who dont want to play the game, but want to shoot you, only for the sake of shooting you. This toxic shoot first, ask questions second environment has become frustrating, unbereable and disheartening for a casual player, which i'm guessing makes the majority of the player base. Forced PvP is ruining the otherwise fenomenal experience this world is set to be.

snippet.textDisplay:
They should add a Halo 3 style shield system where you get like a pretend shield bar and warning system that basically tells you that you have no shields left, when in reality you can still take 1 more shot before getting your shield actually broken. Except here implemented intentionally to make getting ambushed less powerful. Like how right now when you get downed, you're immune to damage for like 2 seconds. They should make losing your shield also make you immune to damage for 2 seconds. BUT SPECIFCALLY only when attacked by a player, and if that attacked initiated combat between players, that way it works as once per combat and only for getting ambushed and still gives the advantage to the ambusher as your shields will be down. That way the game can still be highly dangerous, but give just that much more wiggle room to not die from random ambush.

Or in a much simpler implementation, shield grow an overshield slowly as the match progresses up to double through out a round, maybe 2.5 minutes, rewarding people for staying out of danger, but is broken by shooting, and not by being shot where it works like sheild normally would. Thus giving people scavenging and getting betrayed the benefit of some additional damage resist. Players that crave combat will simply face the reality that the advantage of a good ambush means having to play better to each success rather than easily get free stuff. And players that go around fighting everyone they see will doubtless go into fights having given away their presence and some amount of ammo to almost no benefit but initiating the fight with the enemy at half shield.

The idea would be in the second case, that the player would have to sneak only and avoid shooting in order to get the overshield benefit, meaning they'd break their shield even just shooting arc. It seems fair to me. 
It can even be lore friendly that maybe that Robot guy added it after watching people always fighting each other as a way to get people to favor fighting arc instead, ironic story beat goes here.
And the idea is basically only the most skilled or the most meek get the benefit by coincidence of not shooting, because shooting, like a Rupert's drop, destroys the overshield from within, where its weaker.

snippet.textDisplay:
I had some asshat come up to me saying "Don't shoot" and I reciprocated. Then they used the "wanna team up?" emote and I thought about it and used the No emote. Idiot IMMEDIATELY starts shooting at me. 

I run down the hall and take some cover to heal up. ANOTHER rando asshat stars shooting at me as I'm taking cover. I run back through where I know there was a friendly player and as I run through, there is yet ANOTHER player who starts firing at me. I run up some stairs, close the doors set up some mines and hide behind cover to heal. Door opens, 1 dumbass comes through and gets dropped. Through another door, yet ANOTHER rando comes in and I hear the downed guy who was chasing me (turns out to be the 2nd guy who shot me on sight for no reason) ask the guy "Hey can you rez me?" and the new guy says "Sorry bro I don't have anything" and he knocks him out. 

I watched the whole thing and had about 10 seconds where I could shoot the guy and kill him probably before he even finished off the guy I just knocked. I didn't though because I assumed he might be friendly since he made it sound like he wasn't opposed to rezzing the guy but had nothing. IMMEDIATELY after punching the guy out, he starts shooting me. Fucking what? That's how he repays the favor of me staring into his fucking soul and deciding NOT to shoot when he would have been dropped?

This sort of behavior in Solos is rare but I have a hunch. It was Stella Montis for one thing and the 1st game of that day for me but also, the last game I had played the day before was one where I heard a guy start shooting and realized he was shooting a player. I'm in one of the tall apartments on Buried City so I go up to try and help the guy out. The guy has already been knocked but I see the asshat trying to come and finish him off to loot him. So, I silenced Anvil his booty and he runs and hides. I throw some nades over at him to try and scare him out of his hidey hole. At some point the guy sneaks around into the other apartment building and comes up to try and confront me but his little ambush fails and I get away.

So, if the "if you shoot other players you'll be placed in lobbies with other shooters" thing COULD be true but it's kinda bullshit that even playing defensively to try and help another player who is being player-killed would count. The game should somehow analyze aggression versus protectiveness.
snippet.textOriginal:
I had some asshat come up to me saying "Don't shoot" and I reciprocated. Then they used the "wanna team up?" emote and I thought about it and used the No emote. Idiot IMMEDIATELY starts shooting at me. 

I run down the hall and take some cover to heal up. ANOTHER rando asshat stars shooting at me as I'm taking cover. I run back through where I know there was a friendly player and as I run through, there is yet ANOTHER player who starts firing at me. I run up some stairs, close the doors set up some mines and hide behind cover to heal. Door opens, 1 dumbass comes through and gets dropped. Through another door, yet ANOTHER rando comes in and I hear the downed guy who was chasing me (turns out to be the 2nd guy who shot me on sight for no reason) ask the guy "Hey can you rez me?" and the new guy says "Sorry bro I don't have anything" and he knocks him out. 

I watched the whole thing and had about 10 seconds where I could shoot the guy and kill him probably before he even finished off the guy I just knocked. I didn't though because I assumed he might be friendly since he made it sound like he wasn't opposed to rezzing the guy but had nothing. IMMEDIATELY after punching the guy out, he starts shooting me. Fucking what? That's how he repays the favor of me staring into his fucking soul and deciding NOT to shoot when he would have been dropped?

This sort of behavior in Solos is rare but I have a hunch. It was Stella Montis for one thing and the 1st game of that day for me but also, the last game I had played the day before was one where I heard a guy start shooting and realized he was shooting a player. I'm in one of the tall apartments on Buried City so I go up to try and help the guy out. The guy has already been knocked but I see the asshat trying to come and finish him off to loot him. So, I silenced Anvil his booty and he runs and hides. I throw some nades over at him to try and scare him out of his hidey hole. At some point the guy sneaks around into the other apartment building and comes up to try and confront me but his little ambush fails and I get away.

So, if the "if you shoot other players you'll be placed in lobbies with other shooters" thing COULD be true but it's kinda bullshit that even playing defensively to try and help another player who is being player-killed would count. The game should somehow analyze aggression versus protectiveness.

snippet.textDisplay: In summary, from my perspective, the game is generally well done. However, we already have enough full-time PvP shooters on the market, and I think it's about time we released games that bring people together to solve challenging tasks. But in the end, it always just boils down to a mindless PvP game. Why not make something new? Because that's exactly what drew people to the game in the first place‚Äînot just constant killing. It's probably too late for this game, but for future ones... don't ruin it again. The market gap is so big, why isn't anyone filling it?

Just one thing about Tagging Grenade, before anyone tries to rush level 3 support bench:
You NEED the blueprint for it. You must find the blueprint for Tagging Grenade before you're able to craft it, so it doesn't matter if you have level 1 or level 3 bench.
Still, leveling benches should be top priority anyways. You just won't have the immediate tools to deal with rats. lil smoke bombs are very useful, though.

snippet.textDisplay:
The combat is simply too unbalanced, just like the weapons. In Arc Raiders, PvP means getting shot from a dark corner, a bush, from behind or while looting 99% of the time. Face to face fights are rare to none existent.
Compared to Hunt, PvP simply isn't good. Sure, there are ambushes and rats there too, but I almost  have a chance to turn the tables - besides of headshots. Whereas in AR, whoever shoots first usually wins. I don't even have time to react because my shield breaks after half a second, and  next half second later, I'm dead.

When I die in Hunt or lose loot last second, my toughts very often "That was a good fight!" I usually know what I did wrong and how I could have won. In Arc Raiders, 99% of the time I think, "I never had a chance, just the next rat attack."
I'm really starting to lose interest.

snippet.textDisplay:
Only issue with the tagging grenades is they are blueprint x(

I've been hoping to get lucky and pick it up for a while now, but no such luck so far.  At least I"ve gotten barricade BP, have started loving to use these and take a set with me at almost all times


Try to get a good spread of consumables and taking a few extra outside of your quick use buttons.  Switching them out as needed can make a huge difference between living or dying in a lot of situations

Heals, shields, and smokes until you are out, should always be taking up 3 your slots.  Smokes, I'd say at least 80-90% of the time, should always take up your 3rd slot.  Smokes used properly can be the difference between life and death, making that successful push or retreat, and its one of the few things besides heals I'd say you always want to have on you at all times.  Normal smokes are night and day better than lil' smokes, but even a smaller, shorter bit of smoke cover is better than none, AND you can easily craft and resupply them in the middle of the match, as long as you went 3 deep into red for the perk

4th slot and higher are utility, and should be switched out as needed.  I normally run a default of lure grenades and adrenaline stims to get me quickly from point A to point B.  Lures can be the difference between life and death if you manage to find yourself in a bad spot with one of the much more lethal Arcs, or even a bit of a swarm of the smaller ones.  Then, once i'm in buildings, or know I am getting into a different kind of engagement, i'll pull out whatever I have found or have on me to push or retreat from a location.  Bring your choice of utility items, and at least 1 stack of grenades of some kind.  Don't be afraid to use what you have, you'll eventually be able to craft almost all of them, and learning how each one works and what you prefer to use is essential

Flames, explosives, ect can force or restrict enemy movement, giving you the opportunity to push or retreat as needed.  There may be times you NEED your grenades to to hit and give their full impact on your opponent, but when you use them with that intent ALONE, you set yourself up for failure when you miss, or the grenade lags out and doesn't hit quite where you need it, or your positioning doesn't match with the line and it bounces off the wall right into your face xD  Or you manage to get them almost landed perfectly, but the enemy manages to react in time and do a full sprint/dodge to get out without damage.  Most of the grenades have enough of a delay that they allow fast reflexes to prevent or mitigate the majority of their effect.  But, as long as you use them with the intent of getting your opponents to react in a way that YOU want, or at least, in a way that they DON'T, even if they don't do any damage at all, they have succeeded in doing something valuable for you


My way of doing things isn't perfect, but I also know I'm not the best at these kinds of games xD  Still, creating some kind of system also helps you get used to regularity, and make your choices on the fly.  Then bringing in some adaptability helps give you the edge, if not to come out on top, at least to hopefully get you out alive

I've been hoping to get lucky and pick it up for a while now, but no such luck so far.  At least I"ve gotten barricade BP, have started loving to use these and take a set with me at almost all times


Try to get a good spread of consumables and taking a few extra outside of your quick use buttons.  Switching them out as needed can make a huge difference between living or dying in a lot of situations

Heals, shields, and smokes until you are out, should always be taking up 3 your slots.  Smokes, I'd say at least 80-90% of the time, should always take up your 3rd slot.  Smokes used properly can be the difference between life and death, making that successful push or retreat, and its one of the few things besides heals I'd say you always want to have on you at all times.  Normal smokes are night and day better than lil' smokes, but even a smaller, shorter bit of smoke cover is better than none, AND you can easily craft and resupply them in the middle of the match, as long as you went 3 deep into red for the perk

4th slot and higher are utility, and should be switched out as needed.  I normally run a default of lure grenades and adrenaline stims to get me quickly from point A to point B.  Lures can be the difference between life and death if you manage to find yourself in a bad spot with one of the much more lethal Arcs, or even a bit of a swarm of the smaller ones.  Then, once i'm in buildings, or know I am getting into a different kind of engagement, i'll pull out whatever I have found or have on me to push or retreat from a location.  Bring your choice of utility items, and at least 1 stack of grenades of some kind.  Don't be afraid to use what you have, you'll eventually be able to craft almost all of them, and learning how each one works and what you prefer to use is essential

Flames, explosives, ect can force or restrict enemy movement, giving you the opportunity to push or retreat as needed.  There may be times you NEED your grenades to to hit and give their full impact on your opponent, but when you use them with that intent ALONE, you set yourself up for failure when you miss, or the grenade lags out and doesn't hit quite where you need it, or your positioning doesn't match with the line and it bounces off the wall right into your face xD  Or you manage to get them almost landed perfectly, but the enemy manages to react in time and do a full sprint/dodge to get out without damage.  Most of the grenades have enough of a delay that they allow fast reflexes to prevent or mitigate the majority of their effect.  But, as long as you use them with the intent of getting your opponents to react in a way that YOU want, or at least, in a way that they DON'T, even if they don't do any damage at all, they have succeeded in doing something valuable for you


My way of doing things isn't perfect, but I also know I'm not the best at these kinds of games xD  Still, creating some kind of system also helps you get used to regularity, and make your choices on the fly.  Then bringing in some adaptability helps give you the edge, if not to come out on top, at least to hopefully get you out alive

snippet.textDisplay:
Restitution Idea:

If you get killed while unarmed and if you never fired a shot that hit the player that killed you, and that player does not have a "bounty" against you, then you can issue a "bounty" on that other player. A bounty allows you or anyone in your friend group to hunt down that specific player and kill them across any server or game, you get an alert of when they are playing and you can be dropped in any ongoing game in which they are playing somewhere near to them with a picture of their current avatar and screen name, and that player will show in game with their name and a star above their player. The bounty lasts until it is cancelled or until the player who has the bounty against them is harmed or killed by a bounty hunter three times. There is a limited number of attempts to jump into a game as a bounty hunter to prevent infinite griefing and ongoing retaliation without harming or killing.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
The most annoying thing about the rats is the way they whine while they‚Äôre crawling around on the floor. 

I was heading to Pilgram‚Äôs peak yesterday to get my last cooling fans, and a flare went up when I was like 100m away. I snuck up on a dude creeping around, and got behind him. I asked him in proximity chat ‚Äúyo. You good?.‚Äù He started looking around, and creeping without responding. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll take that as a no‚Äù, I said. He kept creeping, so I took him down. 

While he‚Äôs crawling ‚Äúwtf man. I was trying to answer you back‚Äù. His microphone worked instantly after getting flared, but didn‚Äôt seem to work when I asked him if he was good. 

He also had a free kit, a blue damaged kit, a blue damaged shield, a jolt mine, and more meds than a free kit gives you.

snippet.textDisplay: What an absolute load of rubbish! It‚Äôs impossible to keep anyone dodgy looking in your peripheral vision while you‚Äôre unloading on the Queen and your solo! And it results in PVP in this game being utter BS. I don‚Äôt mind dying when it‚Äôs an exchange of damage and I‚Äôm out PVPd.
